awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Countermeasures Against Side-Channels Attacks Targeting Hardware and Embedded System Implementations of Post-Quantum Cryptographic Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum computers are believed to have a potential to perform specialized calculations beyond the reach of any supercomputer in existence today, threatening today's major public-key cryptography standards. Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) is devoted to the design and analysis of cryptographic algorithms that are resistant against any known attacks using quantum computers, but by themselves can be implemented using classical computing platforms, based on current semiconductor technologies. This project aims to develop effective methods of protecting the implementations of emerging PQC schemes against powerful side-channel attacks based on exploiting power consumption of cryptographic devices and/or intentional transient faults affecting their operation.

The algorithms to be investigated represent several major PQC families and three major categories of public-key cryptography applications: encryption, digital signature, and key encapsulation mechanism. The goal of the project is to determine the cost of effective countermeasures against power and fault attacks in terms of the commonly accepted software and hardware performance metrics. The research thrusts will (i) investigate the effects of countermeasures against fault attacks on resiliency to power attacks, and (ii) propose solutions to achieve combined fault and power analysis resiliency. The project will involve several significant extensions to preliminarily-developed experimental platform: Flexible Open-source workBench fOr Side-channel analysis (FOBOS).

Power and fault attacks are real threats to practical implementation of PQC and may significantly thwart the successful transition to new standards. This project will investigate systematic, long-term study of countermeasures against these attacks, which may make transition to PQC more secure, benefiting Internet users worldwide. The outreach activities will include motivational lectures at high schools, promoting and supervising undergraduate research, and organizing a series of international competitions for graduate students. The knowledge and experience gained will be integrated into several course modules, developed jointly by all investigators and shared on-line.

It is expected that multiple algorithms, computer-aided design tools, software programs, and hardware designs will be developed throughout the project period. Project deliverables will be made available to researchers and educators in the non-profit sector, such as universities, research institutions, and government laboratories. To make it easy to maintain, disseminate, and distribute code and data from this project, a single server will be dedicated to keeping all the draft and final copies of the deliverables. This server will be maintained through the project period and additional five years beyond. The project website will be continuously available at http://www.pqcSCA.com.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview and Goals

The goal of this project was to develop a comprehensive framework for evaluating the resilience of post-quantum cryptography (PQC) algorithms against side-channel attacks (SCA), specifically focusing on power and fault attacks. We aimed to investigate at least one algorithm from each of the five major PQC families, with particular emphasis on the NIST PQC winners. These selected algorithms represented three core categories of public key applications: encryption, digital signatures, and key encapsulation mechanisms (KEM).

Our project's focus was to assess the cost and difficulty of implementing effective countermeasures against SCA while maintaining acceptable software and hardware performance. Additionally, we sought to propose novel countermeasures to secure both individual functional blocks and complete cryptographic systems.

  1. Evaluation of PQC Algorithms

    We successfully evaluated various PQC algorithms, including those from the NIST PQC winners, across the categories of encryption, digital signatures, and KEM. This allowed us to understand the trade-offs between security and performance in real-world cryptographic systems. The evaluation process aligned with the ongoing NIST standardization efforts, ensuring our findings are relevant and timely.

  2. Enhanced Evaluation Platform

    A significant achievement was the expansion of our evaluation platform, which was developed to analyze side-channel leakage. This upgrade enabled comprehensive fault and power attack simulations, which were crucial in understanding the vulnerability of PQC algorithms to real-world attacks.

  3. Countermeasures Investigation

    We focused on investigating how fault attack countermeasures affect resilience to power attacks and proposed solutions to protect against combined fault and power analysis attacks. Our novel countermeasures were designed to improve the security of PQC algorithms, ensuring they remain robust even in the face of sophisticated implementation-level attacks.

  4. Support for NIST PQC Standardization

    Our research has contributed directly to the NIST PQC standardization process. We published findings on the NIST PQC winners, which provided insights into their vulnerability to side-channel attacks. This work supports NIST's ongoing efforts to assess and standardize PQC algorithms, offering guidance for the future deployment of secure post-quantum cryptographic systems.

  5. Exploring the New Signature Competition

    With the launch of the NIST signature competition in July 2023, our project is well-positioned to extend its scope to include the new signature candidates. By integrating these new algorithms into our evaluation framework, we ensure that our research remains relevant and responsive to the latest developments in the PQC field.

Impact and Future Directions

This project has made a significant contribution to the field of PQC by addressing the practical security challenges associated with side-channel attacks. The novel countermeasures we proposed will help ensure that PQC systems are secure as they transition from theoretical designs to practical, real-world applications.

The results of this project will be instrumental in shaping the future of post-quantum cryptography, ensuring that new cryptographic standards are both secure and efficient. As PQC algorithms continue to be adopted, the insights gained from this research will guide future efforts to protect these systems from side-channel vulnerabilities.

Conclusion

This project has achieved its key objectives, providing a solid foundation for the protection of PQC algorithms against side-channel attacks, particularly power and fault attacks. Our contributions to NIST's standardization efforts and the development of novel countermeasures have enhanced the understanding of how to secure PQC systems. The ongoing exploration of the NIST signature competition ensures that our research will continue to evolve and influence the development of secure post-quantum cryptographic systems. We expect that the results of our work have significant impact beyond 2025 on the PQC standrads.
